physDesc.p: This letter is two pages long, printed on plain paper. The words “Little Review” are written in pencil at the top

div.p: I am delighted to know that the rumours of the cessation of “The Little Review” were unfounded, for what I should do without it, both as reader and contributor, I do not know.

I am enclosing my article on “The Poetry Bookshop,” which I agreed to write so many months ago. I am positively ashamed to have had it linger so long; but my French lectures took so much of my time that I was unable to get it out before.

Mr. Fletcher tells me that he is writing to suggest to you a special Imagist number of “The Little Review.” I told him I did not think you would consider such a thing for a moment, as I did not think you wished your paper to have special numbers. And as a matter of fact, in case you may have got a wrong idea of my attitude from anything which he has said, let me say that I do not think a special Imagist number of “The Little Review” would be at all feasible.

In the first place, “The Egoist,” London, is bringing out a special Imagist number, in which are appearing critical articles and poems of all the members in the group. I have arranged with a bookshop in Boston and with another in New York, each to take fifty copies of the paper and have it on sale. Now it would be far from courteous for us American members of the Imagist group to do less for our English brethren than they did for us. They invited us to send both articles and poems for their number, which we did. Now if you do the same thing, it will not only take some time to get the articles back over here which would give the already printed “Egoist” an enormous start over you, making your information second-fiddle and lacking in novelty, but
I think it would be very difficult to get another series of critical articles upon us written by entirely different people.

Again, there is another consideration. I do not think it would be quite cricket for you in Chicago to have a special Imagist number, when the Imagists, as a group, seem to be so closely identified with “Poetry.” And a special Imagist number of “Poetry” would be ridiculous, considering that Miss Monroe introduced the group and has boomed it ever since.

All these reasons seem to me cogent why a special Imagist number of “The Little Review” would be a mistake. Of course, you will do as you please, but I am sure that anything of the sort gotten up over here, unless it were definitely edited by somebody who understands the aims and objects of the group, would get into terribly hot water, as whatever they may individually be willing to do, as a group the Imagists are very touchy about having their opinions represented exactly.
That is a long screed all about nothing, for I am quite certain, as I said before, that such an idea would not appeal to you in the least.
Do not forget to sign our Anthology review “George Lane.” There would be the Devil to pay if we were ever found out.
The enclosed “Bookshop” article, please put in over my own name. And proofs, proofs, dear Lady, where are your proofs?
